com.apriori.util

Class Cloners

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.util.Cloners

  • public class Cloners
extends Object
    Utility methods and constants for using and creating Cloner instances.
    Author:
    Joshua Humphries (jhumphries131@gmail.com)

    • Field Detail

      • GENERIC_CLONER

        public static Cloner<Object> GENERIC_CLONER
        A generic cloner that will try to clone any type of object. Its strategy for cloning objects follows the same flow as defaultClonerFor(Class) except that it evaluates the logic for every object cloned instead of trying to do it statically based on a given type.

        So it is more flexible than defaultClonerFor(Class) since you don't have to know the runtime type of objects being cloned ahead of time. But its performance is worse and cloning may result in runtime exceptions during the cloning operation, instead of when creating the cloner. This occurs if a given object to be cloned is not array and implements neither Cloneable nor Serializable and whose class does not provide a suitable copy constructor.

    • Method Detail

      • checkClone

        public static void checkClone(Object orig,
              Object clone)
        Checks that the clone is valid. This will assert that the clone is not the same instance as the original object and also assert that its class is identical to that of the original.

        The utility method is used by implementations of Cloner in this class and is recommended for use by other custom implementations of Cloner.

        Parameters:
        orig - The original object
        clone - The object's clone

      • forCloneable

        public static <T extends Cloneable> Cloner<T> forCloneable()
        Returns a cloner for cloning instances of Cloneable. This uses the instance's clone() method but furthermore checks that the resulting clone is the same class but not the same instance as the source instance. So classes that implement Cloneable, but in non-standard ways, may not be suitable and may cause exceptions to occur during cloning.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object cloned
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use an object's clone() method to perform the cloning operation

      • forSerializable

        public static <T extends Serializable> Cloner<T> forSerializable()
        Returns a cloner for cloning instances of Serializable. This will actually serialize and de-serialize the object to create the clone. It furthermore checks that the resulting clone is the same class but not the same instance as the source instance. So classes that use custom serialization via writeReplace() and/or readResolve() methods may not be suitable.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object cloned
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use object serialization and de-serialization to perform the cloning operation

      • findCopyConstructor

        public static <T> Constructor<T> findCopyConstructor(Class<T> clazz)
        Finds a copy constructor for the specified class. This requires that the class have a single argument constructor that accepts a compatible argument type.

        If there are multiple such copy constructors (like one that takes precisely the same type and an alternate constructor whose parameter is a super-type) then the one with the most specific type is returned. The class hierarchy is checked first, so a constructor that accepts a super-class or ancestor class is preferred over constructors that accept compatible interfaces, with an exception made for constructors that take Object (which is the least specific). Next, interfaces declared on the class itself are checked and then ancestors of the declared interfaces. Then interfaces declared on the super-class are checked and so on and so forth.

        If multiple constructors are found with the same level of "specificity" then an exception will be thrown. This can happen, for example, when no constructor accepts the specified class or an ancestor class and more than one constructor exists that each accept an interface declared on the class.

        The following example demonstrates how the level of specificity is determined. Given the following (contrived) interfaces and classes 

         interface Interface1A1 {}
 
 interface Interface1A extends Interface1A1 {}
 
 interface Interface1B {}
 
 interface Interface1 extends Interface1A, Interface1B {}
 
 interface Interface2A {}
 
 interface Interface2B {}
 
 interface Interface2 extends Interface2A, Interface2B {}
 
 interface Interface3 {}
 
 class Class1 {} // implicitly extends Object
 
 class Class2 extends Class1 implements Interface2, Interface3 {}
 
 class Class3 extends Class2 {}
 
 class MyClass extends Class3 implements Interface1 {}
        the following details the level of specificity for each eligible constructor argument type when searching for a copy constructor for MyClass:
        Most Specific (preferred) MyClass
        Ancestor classes... Class3
        Class2
        Class1
        Interfaces for MyClass Interface1
        Super-interfaces Interface1A, Interface1B
        Interface1A1
        Interfaces for ancestor classes... Interface2, Interface3
        Interface2A, Interface2B
        Least Specific (last resort) Object
        As seen in the table above, Interface1A and Interface1B have the same level of specificity. So if MyClass only had two compatible constructors, one that took an Interface1A and one that took an Interface1B, then an exception would be thrown because it is ambiguous which constructor should be used. If, however, the class also had a constructor that took a Class1 then that constructor would be used since it is more specific than the other two.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object to be copied
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class token for the type of object to be copied and the class that must have the copy constructor
        Returns:
        The copy constructor or null if no compatible constructor exists
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the choice of constructor is ambiguous because there are multiple such constructors with the same level of specificity
        NullPointerException - If the specified class token is null

      • findStaticCopyMethod

        public static <T> Method findStaticCopyMethod(Class<T> clazz,
                              String methodName)
        Finds a static copy method for the specified class with the specified name. This requires that the class have a single argument method with the specified name that accepts a compatible argument type.

        This will involve the same "specificity" semantics as findCopyConstructor(Class) when searching for the copy method.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object to be copied
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class token for the type of object to be copied and the class that must have the copy method
        methodName - The name of the static copy method
        Returns:
        The static copy method or null if no compatible method with the specified name exists
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the choice of method is ambiguous because there are multiple such methods with the same level of specificity
        NullPointerException - If the specified class token is null

      • withCopyConstructor

        public static <T> Cloner<T> withCopyConstructor(Constructor<T> cons)
        Returns a cloner that uses the specified copy constructor to perform the cloning operation. The constructor should take no arguments or take a single argument that is the object being copied.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        cons - The constructor to use to create a clone
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use the constructor to create a clone
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified constructor requires more than one argument or requires an argument that is a primitive type
        NullPointerException - If the specified constructor is null

      • withCopyConstructor

        public static <T> Cloner<T> withCopyConstructor(Class<T> clazz)
        Returns a cloner that uses a class's copy constructor to perform the cloning operation. This requires that the class have a single-argument constructor that accepts a compatible type.

        The copy constructor to use is determined by findCopyConstructor(Class). If multiple constructors are found with the same level of "specificity" then an exception will be thrown and withCopyConstructor(Class, Class) or withCopyConstructor(Constructor) should be used instead.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class token for the type of object being cloned
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use a copy constructor to create a clone
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified class has no suitable copy constructor or if it has multiple constructors of the same level specificity
        NullPointerException - If the specified class token is null
        See Also:
        findCopyConstructor(Class)

      • withCopyConstructor

        public static <T> Cloner<T> withCopyConstructor(Class<T> clazz,
                                Class<? super T> argClazz)
        Returns a cloner that uses a class's copy constructor to perform the cloning operation. This requires that the class have a single-argument constructor that accepts the specified type.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class token for the type of object being cloned
        argClazz - The argument type of the copy constructor
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use a copy constructor to create a clone
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified class has no matching constructor
        NullPointerException - If either of the specified class tokens is null

      • withCopyMethod

        public static <T> Cloner<T> withCopyMethod(Method method)
        Returns a cloner that uses the specified copy method to perform the cloning operation. If the method is a static method then it should take no arguments or take a single argument that is the object being copied. If the method is an instance method then it should take no arguments and the instance it is invoked on will be the object being copied.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        method - The method to use to create a clone
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use the method to create a clone
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified method requires more than one argument or requires an argument that is a primitive type
        NullPointerException - If the specified method is null

      • withInstanceCopyMethod

        public static <T> Cloner<T> withInstanceCopyMethod(Class<T> clazz,
                                   String methodName)
        Returns a cloner that uses an instance method on the class to perform the cloning operation. This requires that the class have a no-argument method with the specified name that accepts a compatible type. The instance method will be invoked on the object to be cloned.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class token for the type of object being cloned
        methodName - The name of the instance method
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use an instance method to create a clone
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified class has no suitable method
        NullPointerException - If either argument is null

      • withStaticCopyMethod

        public static <T> Cloner<T> withStaticCopyMethod(Class<T> clazz,
                                 String methodName)
        Returns a cloner that uses a static method on the class to perform the cloning operation. This requires that the class have a single-argument method with the specified name that accepts a compatible type.

        The copy method to use is determined by findStaticCopyMethod(Class, String). If multiple matching methods are found with the same level of "specificity" then an exception will be thrown and withStaticCopyMethod(Class, String, Class) or withCopyMethod(Method) should be used instead.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class token for the type of object being cloned
        methodName - The name of the static method
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use a static method to create a clone
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified class has no suitable static method or if it has multiple such methods of the same level specificity
        NullPointerException - If either argument is null
        See Also:
        findStaticCopyMethod(Class, String)

      • withStaticCopyMethod

        public static <T> Cloner<T> withStaticCopyMethod(Class<T> clazz,
                                 String methodName,
                                 Class<? super T> argClazz)
        Returns a cloner that uses a static method on the class to perform the cloning operation. This requires that the class have a single-argument method with the specified name that accepts the specified type.

        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class token for the type of object being cloned
        methodName - The name of the static method
        argClazz - The argument type of the static method
        Returns:
        A cloner that will use a static method to create a clone
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified class has no matching static method
        NullPointerException - If any of the arguments are null

      • fromInstance

        public static <T> Cloner<T> fromInstance(T clone)
        Creates a cloner that just returns the specified object. This is useful when the clone is created beforehand and needs to be embedded in a Cloner interface. The cloner will perform a check that the specified clone object has the same class as the object to be cloned and is not the same instance as the object being cloned.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        clone - The clone
        Returns:
        A cloner that returns clone (regardless of the object passed to Cloner.clone(Object))
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the specified instance is null

      • fromInstances

        public static List<Cloner<?>> fromInstances(Object... clones)
        Creates a list of cloners that just return the specified objects. This is useful when the clones are created beforehand and need to be embedded in Cloner interfaces. The cloners will perform checks that the specified clone objects have the same classes as the objects to be cloned and are not the same instances as the objects being cloned.
        Parameters:
        clones - The clones
        Returns:
        A list of cloners
        See Also:
        fromInstances(List)

      • fromInstances

        public static List<Cloner<?>> fromInstances(List<?> clones)
        Creates a list of cloners that just return the specified objects. This is useful when the clones are created beforehand and need to be embedded in Cloner interfaces. The cloners will perform checks that the specified clone objects have the same classes as the objects to be cloned and are not the same instances as the objects being cloned.

        The returned list will have cloners in the same order as the specified clones. So the first cloner in the list will return the first item from the provided list of clones.

        If any null values are specified as clones, the corresponding cloner in the returned list will also be null. This is useful for specifying cloners to InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator#cloneArgumentsWith(List) under situations where some of the method arguments do not need to be cloned (like if they are null, primitive, or not subject to mutation by the method under test).

        Parameters:
        clones - The clones
        Returns:
        A list of cloners
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the specified list is null

      • fromCallable

        public static <T> Cloner<T> fromCallable(Callable<T> c)
        Creates a cloner that gets the clone from the specified object. Since Callable.call() does not take any parameters, the clone must be agnostic to the actual value being cloned. From that perspective, this is similar to using fromInstance(Object).
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object being cloned
        Parameters:
        c - The object called to get the clone
        Returns:
        A cloner that calls the specified object and returns the result as the clone
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the specified instance is null
        See Also:
        fromInstance(Object)

      • forArray

        public static <T> Cloner<T[]> forArray(Cloner<T> cloner)
        Creates a cloner for arrays that performs a deep copy by using the specified cloner to clone elements. If you want a cloner that does a shallow copy of the array, you can use forCloneable() since arrays in Java implement Cloneable.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The element type of the array
        Parameters:
        cloner - The cloner for copying elements
        Returns:
        A cloner for deep-copying arrays
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the specified cloner is null

      • forNestedArray

        public static <T> Cloner<T[]> forNestedArray(Class<T[]> arrayClass,
                             Cloner<?> cloner)
        Creates a cloner for arrays that performs a deep copy by cloning all array elements. The "leaf" components (not arrays) will be cloned using the specified cloner. The rest of the structure, regardless of nesting depth, will be deep copied in the resulting clone. This can be useful if you have a cloner for SpreadsheetCell and a sheet of cells represented by a two-dimensional array of these objects: SpreadsheetCell[][]. In such a case, a cloner for this structure could be build like so: 
         Cloner<SpreadsheetCell> cellCloner = new MyCellCloner();
 Cloner<SpreadsheetCell[][]> sheetCloner =
       Cloners.forNestedArray(SpreadsheetCell[][].class, cellCloner);
        This is effectively shorthand for repeated calls to forArray(Cloner) that look like this: 
         Cloner<SpreadsheetCell> cellCloner = new MyCellCloner();
 Cloner<SpreadsheetCell[]> rowCloner = Cloners.forArray(cellCloner);
 Cloner<SpreadsheetCell[][]> sheetCloner = Cloners.forArray(rowCloner);
        And this method works, regardless of nesting depth. So the following call is just as valid and will create a cloner for a four-dimensional array (and will save even more typing since using forArray with a four-dimensional array is even more verbose): 
         Cloner<MyObject> elementCloner = new MyObjectCloner();
 Cloner<MyObject[][][][]> matrixCloner =
       Cloners.forNestedArray(MyObject[][][][].class, elementCloner);
        Type Parameters:
        T - The component type of the array type to clone (which can itself be an array type since this method is designed to work with nested arrays)
        Parameters:
        arrayClass - The class token for the array type to clone
        cloner - The cloner for cloning leaf components
        Returns:
        A cloner for deep-copying arrays
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If either argument is null

      • defaultClonerFor

        public static <T> Cloner<T> defaultClonerFor(Class<T> clazz)
        Creates a "default" cloner for the specified class. The default cloner is chosen like so:
        • If the type represents an array then forArray(Cloner) is used to create a cloner that deep copies arrays. Elements in the array will be cloned by a "default" cloner for their type.
        • If the type implements Cloneable then forCloneable() is used to create the cloner.
        • If the type implements Serializable then forSerializable() is used.
        • Otherwise, withCopyConstructor(Class) is used to create the cloner.
        If the type is not an array, implements neither interface, and has no suitable copy constructor then an exception is thrown. Similarly, if the type is an array but has an element type that implements neither interface and has no suitable copy constructor then an exception is thrown.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of object to be cloned
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class token for the type of object to be cloned
        Returns:
        A cloner for the specified type
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the specified class token is null
